Award.AwardTitle: FSML-Enhanced Cooperative Radiochemistry Research and Education at the Bigelow Laboratory for Ocean Sciences
Award.AbstractNarration:
Bigelow Laboratory is awarded a grant to outfit their new Radiochemistry Facility with 1) a Liquid Scintillation Counter (LSC) for low-level counting, 2) two dedicated, stackable incubators for maintaining radiochemistry experiments at different temperature and light conditions and 3) two photosynthetron incubators with dedicated water baths for measuring photobiological rates of phytoplankton as a function of light intensity. Indeed, this equipment is critical to the functionality of the facility as well as the very mission of the laboratory. The ability to accurately measure radio-tracers has been at the very core of Bigelow Laboratory?s primary goal, "to understand key processes driving the world's ocean ecosystems, their evolution, and their fundamental relationship to life on Earth." This FSML request for radiochemistry equipment will allow the PIs to maintain preeminence in the measurement of microbial rates in the sea. Bigelow Laboratory's senior research scientists work with ocean viruses, bacteria, phytoplankton, zooplankton, and lower invertebrates. They no longer study just the processes of the euphotic zone but have added major research programs including atmospheric chemistry, hydrothermal vent communities, and microbes of the deep geosphere. What unifies all these groups is the need to measure rates: biological rates (uptake, assimilation, growth, mortality, grazing) and chemical rates (oxidation, reduction, gas exchange/ equilibration). Radiotracer technologies still represent one of the best ways to quantitatively (and directly) measure such rates in the sea.

Broader Impacts

This research equipment will be involved in the training of current and future Bigelow postdoctoral researchers, working at the interface between microbial ecology, physiology, molecular biology, and biogeochemistry. A significant part of Bigelow Laboratory's mission is education and it has a strong outreach program. Co-PIs in this proposal are involved in teaching the Colby semester-in-residence program as well as Colby's January Program ("Jan-plan"). Specific details and scientific results from the LSC will be incorporated into the curriculum of our undergraduate students so they can learn the fundamentals of tracer experiments and the technology associated with the LSC. Bigelow Laboratory's Caf√© Scientifique lecture series promotes public engagement with cutting-edge scientific research, of the sort made possible by this equipment, making science more accessible to a broader audience. All PIs on this project will participate in this increasingly popular program. POR.DRECONTENT:
This Project Outcomes Report describes the results of a grant from the National Science Foundation for improvements in Facilities, communications, and equipment at biological field stations and marine laboratories (FSML). 

Intellectual merit- The goals of this FSML grant were to purchase several pieces of equipment associated with Bigelow Laboratory's new radiochemistry facility: a high sensitivity scintillation counter (to replace Bigelow's aged instrument, no longer supported by the manufacturer), two new environmental incubators (to allow multiple investigators to perform experiments simultaneously in the radiochemistry laboratory) and two new "photosynthetrons" (temperature-controlled incubators that allow the measurement of light-dependent processes [primarily marine plants but also marine bacteria and viruses]), at the heart of Bigelow Laboratory's mission.  All the equipment was purchased and has now become central for the research conducted by a number of principal investigators at Bigelow Laboratory. It is being actively integrated into the work of seven laboratories at Bigelow Laboratory.

Broader impacts- The new equipment is being heavily used by Bigelow's postdocs for their research and training.  The types of measurements performed by the FSML instrumentation are allowing Bigelow investigators to pursue work in the fields of phytoplankton physiology, microbiology and biogeochemistry.  Moreover, results from these instruments have been used in teaching and mentoring of summer REU students at Bigelow.  The new scintillation counter is directly interfaced with the laboratory's high-performance computing facility which allows great ease and speed in data sharing and data submission (not possible with our previous  scintillation counter).  Overall, the new instrumentation allows better data distribution and preservation.  Results from these instruments have been a) disseminated  at six conference presentations, b) written-up for six research papers and c) used in several new proposals submitted for new research projects.
